key_insight: WorldCanvas enables promptable, user-directed event simulation by jointly conditioning on natural language, motion trajectories (timing, visibility), and reference images, producing coherent and controllable visual events that go beyond text-only or trajectory-only methods.
problem_solved: Existing image-to-video and text-only generation systems struggle to simultaneously control motion, timing, object identity, and semantic intent; WorldCanvas addresses the gap by fusing trajectories, reference visuals, and language for precise, grounded event synthesis.
method: Multimodal conditioning: combine natural language for intent, explicit trajectories for motion/timing/visibility, and reference images for visual identity.
Trajectory encoding: represent motion and temporal visibility as structured controls that guide event progression.
Generative conditioning pipeline: feed the fused multimodal representation into a video/image generation model to produce coherent, controllable event sequences.
impact: This approach gives practitioners fine-grained, intuitive control over generated events—useful for simulation, content creation, and data augmentation—by making motion, timing, and visual identity directly promptable.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing three inputs (text, trajectory timeline, reference image) merging into a generation model and producing a sequence of frames.
Before/after examples: a reference image + trajectory + text prompt on the left and the resulting event frames on the right.
Trajectory timeline illustration: arrows, visibility windows, and timing ticks to explain how motion and occlusion are encoded.
Icon set: speech bubble (language), curved arrow/track (trajectory), photo/frame (reference image) to represent the three conditioning modalities.
paper_title: The World is Your Canvas: Painting Promptable Events with Reference Images, Trajectories, and Text
paper_authors: Hanlin Wang, Hao Ouyang, Qiuyu Wang, Yue Yu, Yihao Meng
